content.caption: The top stories of 2014 have two dominant themes: the accomplishments of individuals and turmoil in our institutions. The year was memorable for the people who shaped it: Kaci Hickox, Nicole Maines, Paul LePage and, yes, the Duck of Justice. But the steady decline of Maine’s paper industry should give pause, as should the difficulties within the University of Maine system, where tensions are high among students, faculty and administration. What’s known is that these storylines will continue into 2015; what’s unknown, and exciting, is who will emerge as Maine’s newsmakers along the way.

Kaci Hickox takes her famous bike ride in Fort Kent in late October, followed by a state police car. Photos of her ride, an act of civil disobedience against a quarantine order by the state of Maine, made international news at the peak of worldwide Ebola fears.

On a crisp October day in Fort Kent, Kaci Hickox took a leisurely bicycle ride and the world would follow every pedal. This act of easy defiance against the Ebola quarantines forced upon her, first in New Jersey, then by Maine, made her a hero to volunteer health care workers and civil libertarians across the world. The worldwide media camped in the dooryard of the Fort Kent home she shared with her boyfriend, nursing student Ted Wilbur. Her story was parodied on “Saturday Night Live” and commemorated in song. When the end of her 21-day quarantine ended, what she knew all along was confirmed: there was no virus. Yet the concerns she raised about the treatment of health care workers who are risking their lives in virus-stricken countries still resonate.

Gov. Paul LePage celebrates his sweeping re-election at the Franco-American Heritage Center in Lewiston. The bombastic and rough-edged LePage was sent back into office by the largest margin seen in Maine in decades.

Gov. Paul LePage was swept back into office in November with the highest margins of electoral victory Maine has seen in years. His romp defied the wisdom espoused by pundits and pollsters, and served notice of a new era in state politics and sensibilities. LePage’s passion and performance on the stump separated him from opponents Rep. Mike Michaud and Eliot Cutler, and earned him a mandate for his pro-business policy agenda of small government, low taxes and welfare reform. At times, LePage was thought the most polarizing person in Maine. It’s now arguable he’s the most popular.

A 14-year-old Nicole Maines (left) and her family listen to applause in 2011 after the family received a Maine ACLU award. The recognition was an early sign that Maines was becoming a national leader for transgender rights.

Once upon a time, a student walked into a restroom in Orono as a relative unknown. Seven years later, Nicole Maines has become a leading advocate for transgender rights and honored as one of Glamour Magazine’s most inspiring women for 2014. In January, the state’s highest court found in Maines’ favor, guaranteeing her right to use the restroom of her choosing. This one small step constituted a giant leap forward for the rights of transgendered people, earning Maines plaudits for standing up for herself and others.

Protesting students, demanding an end to faculty cuts at the University of Southern Maine, took over a board of trustees meeting in November. It was the latest salvo in ongoing skirmishes between UMaine students and faculty and administration.

A budget crisis within the UMaine system has fractured relationships between faculty and the administration, while fomenting a mini-revolution among students, particularly at the University of Southern Maine. Student protests at that school became commonplace as faculty and program cuts were rolled out to help bridge a deficit estimated to be $90 million across the system by 2020. Trustees were besieged in Portland and pilloried for moving a meeting about USM cuts to Fort Kent, plus a leading faculty group demanded an investigation into whether the crisis is real. It was a tough year, and there’s more to come.

The owner of this former used car dealership in Bangor, Glenn Geiser, was sued by the state for engaging in deceptive and fraudulent practices. The dealership is closed, but lawsuits against Geiser continue.

This year, the floodgates opened up on car dealer Glenn Geiser, as the state of Maine smacked his “My Maine Ride” dealership with a litany of allegations of fraudulent and predatory sales practices. The boisterous Geiser of television and radio advertisements was humbled, settling the lawsuit from the AG by relinquishing his license and paying $30,000 in damages to customers. His dealership is gone. For his part, Geiser now sounds contrite, saying “the fight is now out of him.” Unfortunately for him, the lawsuits are still coming.

Gary Alexander, flanked by a colleague from his consulting company and Department of Health and Human Services Commissioner Mary Mayhew, prepares for questioning from lawmakers. Hired for about $1 million to analyze Maine’s Medicaid system, the report he produced plagiarized from other sources, quickly discrediting Alexander and his work.

A near million-dollar, no-bid contract to influential consultant Gary Alexander to study Maine’s Medicaid system became a political firestorm, even before the Bangor Daily News revealed that parts of the study were plagiarized from other sources. Alexander was yanked before lawmakers to explain himself, and Gov. Paul LePage canceled the contract of the guy he initially wanted to run the Department of Health and Human Services. Alexander’s report never amounted to anything and the $475,000 paid to his firm was not returned.
John Winkin, legendary baseball coach, leads a youth clinic in 1992.

He played bridge with Hall of Fame football coach Vince Lombardi, was a lieutenant commander on a Navy destroyer during World War II and wrote his thesis at Duke University on how to turn the double play. Yet John Winkin will be best remembered for guiding the University of Maine baseball team to unprecedented heights in the 1970s and ’80s. The New Jersey native took over at UMaine in 1975 and directed the Black Bears to six College World Series while mentoring a handful of future pros. Winkin, who amassed 1,043 victories in 46 seasons as a college head coach, died in July at age 94, 6½ years after suffering a stroke that left him partially paralyzed and forced him into retirement after a half-century in the dugout.

After Rusty Brace, a pillar of the Camden community, was accused of embezzling from the charity he stewarded for years, small signs were posted throughout the town stating the amount: $3.8 million. The identity of the sign poster was never discovered.

The rumors started swirling, but no one thought they could be true. When the truth came out, a pillar of the Camden community, Rusty Brace, stood accused of pilfering $3.8 million from the charity he had stewarded for years. The realization broke the trust of those who donated regularly for years, who served with Brace on untold community boards and committees, and the board members of the charity. A criminal investigation is ongoing and Brace’s assets are being liquidated to repay the debt. The damage, however, is done.
At the conclusion of this auction in early December, the remains of Great Northern paper were sold for $5.4 million. Its future is unknown.

With nary a straight answer for months, Cate Street Capital left the towns of Millinocket and East Millinocket up river by declaring bankruptcy and pulling the plug on the remaining hopes of restarting the paper machines of Great Northern. All the strings on Cate Street’s Byzantine corporate structure have yet to be pulled. Meanwhile, a turnaround company from California bought the East Millinocket mill at auction (pictured here) and may have a plan. Those in the Katahdin region are hoping so.
Expera Specialty Solutions, a Wisconsin paper company, is the latest outfit to restart Old Town Fuel & Fiber and give the mill — and its workers — renewed viability.

In Old Town, time ran out on mill owner Patriarch Partners, who closed mill operations with the suddenness of a lightning strike in August. Its bankruptcy ended better than most, as a paper company from Wisconsin scooped it up to make pulp and put its people back to work. There are paper-related products being made in Old Town again.
Lexi Pelkey, 6, holds a "We believe in Bucksport" sign during the community rally on the last day of papermaking at the Verso mill.

Just weeks before the election, Verso paper shocked coastal Maine by announcing the upcoming closure of its Bucksport mill and putting over 500 people out of work by Christmas. Coming on the heels of Old Town and Great Northern, the announcement stung the state, changed the political winds and galvanized a community to support the men and women who worked in that mill their whole lives. “Bucksport Strong” read some of the signs at the rally on the last day of work. It certainly is.

The Duck of Justice, a tongue-in-cheek social media creation of the Bangor Police Department, has earned a national fan following and recognition for Bangor as an innovator in community policing through technology.

Move over Paul Bunyan. The official mascot of Bangor isn’t a bearded gentleman of great stature, wielding an axe and peavey, but a small waterfowl with a badge. The Bangor Police Department’s “Duck of Justice” made headlines with its social media debut, inspiring fans near and far, and even its own line of clothing. Quack.

Brenda White of LaGrange carries bear bait to a site located on timberland near Lincoln. Her husband, Troy, runs Mid Maine Outfitters, which organizes bear hunts, and will continue to do so after the defeat of Question 1 in November.

The vote about baiting, hounding and trapping bears in Maine, the second of its kind in 10 years, ended the same as the first. Along the way, it sparked deep debate about the true nature of hunting, Maine’s rural traditions and economy and the role of public agencies in political advocacy. Although nothing changed from the vote, its repercussions will be felt for awhile. Undoubtedly, too, Maine will discuss these issues again.
Memorial hearts flutter in the breeze across from 20-24 Noyes St. in Portland, where fire killed five people the morning after Halloween.

On Halloween night, a fire swept through a house on Noyes Street in Portland and claimed six lives. It was the deadliest fire in recent Maine history. The grief of the midcoast families — two of the victims were from Rockland — was palpable, as questions about how the fire started — and how it could have been prevented — remain unanswered.
